instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello

Little corrosion around smc, cleaned and reflowed.

GREEN LIGHT: OK
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL>: 12.8V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>:3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.6V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.6V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>: 0V

Any idea?
Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
If detected, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>: Drop Pulse ok

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>: Nothing happens, always 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
What about <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and RTC signals?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 560mV"
Must fix this!
Original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger for sure?

Check <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Always worked with these boards with PS, but confirmed with known good 85W MS and same issue. 

<RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR>: 9.98KOhm (out of the board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I reballed the SMC and same issue. Should I try with another one? (If so, could I use one from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Test starting the board with both charger and (known good) battery connected.
Also try SMC bypass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I do not have a known good battery to test at the moment. 

Customers battery seems to be charging but no power.

Tested with Original 85W and customers battery and no power. 

SMC Bypass same problem. 

Should I try ultrasonic cleaner? (Since I found some corrosion around SMC)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Try known good SMC, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Could I use one from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
It may boot the board, but is not recommended.
You can get weird issues...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I replaced the SMC (from a  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ) and now I get the:

-<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 5V
-All big coils voltages (including CPU ones)
-<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>: 0V
-<SIGNAL>TBTBST_BOOST</SIGNAL>: 0V
-the board takes 300mA 
-power button responds
-no video

Do you think this can be an issue of the SMC no beign from the same model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you test USB activity?

As now you've confirmed to have bad (original) SMC, find another from 4924 donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I replaced the SMC for one of the same model board but same issue. 

-No video on screen
-No external video
-Takes 800mA
-CPU gets hot
-Tried other BIOS (from the donor board) and same
-No USB activity detected.

Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and theyr traces.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

Try known good BIOS, should be posted on the forum.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Same issue
-All  "SPI Bus Series Termination" resistors in page 47 are ok. (All 22ohms) 
-tried this bios your provided and same [URL]https://drive.google.com/file/d/18m-YhIlNhX4Uf5njH8KHmRGZelvEXnD_/view[/URL]

Any idea? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?"

Be sure traces between all SPI resistors are good.
Also check solders and traces of <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>.
Inspect J6100 for corrosion.
